title: Thursday, 26th September 2019
bodyHTML:
VV75 morning
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Happy Pearson Profit Warning Day everyone.

Soundbuy Morning

chomsky wagwan everyone

Good lord, how obvious? How absolutely screamingly well flagged was this one?

BE11:07am

The upshot of the argument being that Pearson is a serial cost cutter that uses disposals and corporate rejiggery to cover up its failings.

BE11:07am

And big talk of investment is exactly that.

BE11:08am

So! "adjusted operating profit will be at the bottom of the guidance range of £590m to £640m"

PBateman Morning all
PBateman Please may I request Imperial Brands for later? Ta
11:08 am
BE11:09am

And who'd have thought! The in structural decline US higher education business is in structural decline, as it has been ever since Napster.

chomsky Juul chief exec leaving role too
BE11:09am

Cutting to Macquarie.

marktime It's that time again
BE11:09am

 The factors that contributed to yet another miss on guidance are:
1) Stronger print attrition as distributors/ students resort to second-hand
books or digital, though Pearson doesn’t seem to benefit from more digital
sales;
2) Share loss (100bps out of 40%) attributed to ERP problems in 2018,
though this could be due to competitors pressure (e.g. Cengage
Unlimited); and,
3) Lower-than-expected digital sales due to lower volumes, with further
specific market share loss in this segment, we believe.

tangledodyssey Yes, PSON notifiable shorts at 7.67%, total shorts could be what, 10% or so?
11:10 am
BE11:10am

We are cutting our EPS 2019-20E by 8% as we lower our US higher education revenue growth to -10% in 2019 and -4% in 2020. Our forecast for operating margin drops to a relatively conservative 15.4% in 2019, but still looks demanding in 2020E (18.5%), which requires a strong performance from new digital products recently launched. We lower our TP to £12.40 (was £12.80) to reflect lower estimates.

BE11:10am

They remain positive "with low conviction, after another negative
surprise."

BE11:10am

Our buy case now rests predominantly on the potential benefit from
digital products recently launched on the Global Learning Platform.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

Yeah, good luck.

marktime The declared impact of the BA strike (so far) was extreme do the analysts have any comment?
marktime Thanks BE I looked at Pearson and its tempting dividend and happily moved on
AC21 Kier heading down this morning; any news?
BE11:13am

Much of the sellside has rather less confidence in and are taking the opportunity to repeat sell.

BE11:13am

Such as Numis.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

We do not expect to have to materially change estimates, as were already towards the low end of guided operating profit range and marginally below lower end EPS guidance, though consensus should come down this morning meaningfully. We retain a Sell recommendation and 559p target.

BE11:13am

..... which is quite "told you so", and justifiably.

cheeckychappy @BE - heard anymore re Babcock International?
Shrink @tangledodyssey, can confirm, as I am among them
BE11:14am

Berenberg:

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Which has this in its morning note, rather presciently.

BE11:15am

We reiterate our Sell rating on Pearson: While the stock has
underperformed over the past 12 months, despite weakness in the pound
sterling (which is beneficial for Pearson and explains the price target
update), we see further downside potential. Our data scrape suggests that
Pearson has lost share in the fall 2019 academic season, and latest third
party industry survey data confirms that students are increasingly skipping
paying for materials and shifting to those they can procure for free. Group
organic revenue growth may be improving, but not all revenues earn the
same margin, and thus we continue to expect the group to miss on profit
metrics. Valuation does not allow for this, in our view. Sell.
● Latest National Association of College Stores (NACS) data shows doubledigit decline in spending: The latest survey data confirms the continuation
of the trend for students to cut expenditure on materials through: a)
reducing the number of courseware items that they procure, and b)
increasing procurement of materials via cost-free channels (borrowing and
downloading free materials). Spring 2019 showed an 11% decline in spend
per student, with a 22% decline in two-year (community college) students
(to whom Pearson over-indexes in terms of its higher education
courseware revenue).
● Latest scrape information: Meanwhile, our latest scrape of online college
bookstores suggests that Pearson has lost share versus Cengage and
McGraw-Hill Education, particularly in the community colleges segment.
This tallies with Cengage management’s claims that the affordability of
Unlimited has driven further double-digit growth in digital unit takeaways
on top of the strong fall adoption season in 2018. We believe that
institutions are increasingly recognising the value inherent in Unlimited.

IMP.GLD Surprised someone hasn't swooped in to take this shambles private
BE11:16am

Goldman. Also sellers.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

We see this release as supportive of our view that the transition to digital within US Higher Ed is not enough to offset the structural headwinds facing the print business. Beyond this, we are sceptical of the financial outlook for digital courseware given higher levels of competition and pricing pressure. For further details of our view please see our previous research.
At the 9M, US higher education courseware declined by c.10%, which the company attributed to an acceleration of the shift from print to digital and continued share loss to McGraw Hill in Developmental Maths. At the group level, Pearson reported flat organic revenue growth for 9M19, with North America down 3%, Core markets up 5% and Growth up 3%.

Tom Dalgleish Pearson sill turns a quid tho. Unlike many newspapers
Tom Dalgleish Do uni students still have a book list?
BE11:16am

And I think Neil Campling joined the pile-on this morning.

BE11:17am

The issue with the Pearson warning is that in recent months the company has made it pretty clear that there was an ongoing recovery in the courseware business – but this problem child is the reason for the warning. At H1 results courseware was down -1% YoY and modest declines were observed in U.S. Higher Education Courseware and Student Assessment. And of note that H1 in this segment U.S. Courseware faced tougher comparison in the first half of 2019 than it did in H1 2018, which was helped by the absence of the additional returns provision that the company took in the first half of 2017.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

This led to revenue declines in line with the middle of the guidance range for the full year of flat to -5%. The pace of decline is clearly accelerating as, at first 9M of 2019, this is now -10%, and the business is expected to fall by 8-12%.

One of the three key tenants of a strategy for growth has been to promote the courseware and assessment shift to digital

CEO Fallon has been in charge of this slowly sinking ship for more than six years now, and the CFO alongside him for four years. It feels like the “midst of a transformation” (as described in the 2017 annual report) is likely to create “red mist” among frustrated shareholders.

(@Tom: the printing cost is of course a book's only expense, as authors survive by eating sand.)

Tom Dalgleish A lotta sand
BE11:24am

Barclays to summarise the numbers.

BE11:24am

IMB has revised its FY19 EPS growth outlook from 4-8% EPS to 0% EPS growth at constant currency.

· FY19 volume outlook remains the same at -4% to -5%, as communicated earlier, indicating 2H19 volumes are in line with our expectations (-2.2%). So why are the earnings missing?

· US and Europe tobacco profit is still growing. Weakness in the Asia, Africa and Australasia division is impacting numbers. In particular, company is highlighting that some inventory gains in Australia are not happening in FY19 but FY20.

Non-operating items of ~GBP30mn this year vs GBP80mn last year, and company’s expectations of GBP 50-100mn earlier.

· FY19 NGP revenues to be up 50%, i.e. GBP280mn, indicating 2H19 NGP of ~140mn, down from 1H19 of ~148mn. There are no IP revenues this year vs last year. It has been clear to us (and the Street) that NGP revenue guidance is too high, based on Nielsen trends. Why the company didn’t chose to rebase it at 1H19 isn’t clear. Why the company is continuing to invest in NGP’s, when there is little evidence of success, will be a big question from here on.

· Company still commenting that “premium cigar business sale progressing in line with expectations.”

· Expect significant downward pressure on stock.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

· This has limited read-across to BAT, MO or PM – we think these are IMB specific execution and communication issues.

chomsky I finished university not long back and I couldn't tell you of anyone that actually spends the £60+ charged for the books. You can find them on amazon for less than £5 or free (semi-legally)
BE11:25am

And UBS

BE11:26am

Net revenue growth is expected to be +2.0%; assuming this is reported terms, this is below consensus (+3.8%) and UBSe (+3.5%). This is also below previous guidance of constant FX revenue growth at the "upper end of 1-4%" (in this update FX is expected to be a 2% translational tailwind to earnings); consensus constant FX sales growth is 3% (UBSe 2.1%). Constant FX EPS growth is expected to be flat for FY19, versus previous guidance of the "lower end" of 4-8% (consensus is at 4.4% reported FX growth). This is partly driven by a lower level of recurring accounting gains (e.g. profit on disposals); £30mn for FY19 vs £80mn for FY18. IMB flagged that revisions to its NGP supply chain may incur further termination costs not included in this guidance.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

IMB has guided for 50% NGP revenue growth, implying £280mn for FY19 revenue – well below £372mn consensus. This also implies a sequential decline in 2H19 NGP revenue versus 1H, from £148mn to £134mn. Within this, IMB flagged challenges in the US due to regulatory (inc state) scrutiny, and 2H19 Europe NGP sales are expected to be flat versus 1H19. Tobacco is expected to deliver "low single digit revenue growth" (unclear if constant FX), and "higher" operating profit – this is broadly in line with June comments that the tobacco business could hit the group targets alone.

BE11:26am

We expect the uncertainties around the execution around NGP strategy to weigh on the shares near term. BAT last updated the market on 12-Sep, reiterating both its NGP and group revenue guidance, limiting any negative read-across, in our view.

BE11:28am

And Morgan Stanley off the conference call.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Imperial provided little comfort on the underlying business model following a cut to FY19 earnings guidance. Management was clear that they saw a decline in the US vape market in September and Imperial's US vape performance suffered because of this. The decline was driven by regulatory disruption leading to retailers halting certain promotions and open system products gaining share. The category remains unprofitable but management expect it to reach breakeven in 2020, which we believe is unlikely, and would largely be a function of improvement in the US business. We forecast 3% earnings decline for 2020e driven by higher NGP investments vs medium term company guidance of 4-8% earnings growth.Still Feeling Blu We think IMB's growth algorithm is at risk from adverse geographic exposure coupled with weaker market positioning amidst a rising RRP revenue pool. We have previously highlighted our view that Imperial has the weakest portfolio in Tobacco, reporting an average LFL of 1% since 2011, significantly lower than its global tobacco peers who have delivered a LFL of 4% in the same period. Imperial continues to see growth across the nicotine market however it is clear the current portfolio mix is holding back performance vs. competitors who are more advanced in Vape, Heat not Burn and Smokeless exposure. In our note Feeling Blu we step through our view that Imperial needs to make material further investment in NGPs to drive revenues and to insulate itself from a rapid shift towards reduced risk products in its top 10 markets (greater than 70% of EBIT).

pancakes or waffles @blank thank you thank you :) though admittedly, i am somewhat cheating with two dates a year if you include national waffle day
BE11:36am

...... FY guidance unchanged but tone cautious.

BE11:36am

Here comes Goldman.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

SSP published its 4Q19 Pre Close Trading Update this morning (26 September). SSP reiterated its FY19 guidance however with somewhat slower LFL growth of “just below” 2% for the full year offset by net contract gains for the full year to be at around 5.5% - slightly above its previous guidance of around 5%.
LFL revenue growth for 4Q19 is expected to come in at c1.8%, down from 2% in 3Q19 (vs. GSe 2.1% 4Q19 implied). For the full year, management now expects LFL growth “just below” 2% vs “around 2%” previously (vs. GSe 2.0%). Offsetting this somewhat slower LFL growth are net contract gains, which management expects to come in at around 5.5% for FY19E vs around 5% previously (GSe: 4.9%) with net contract gains of 6% expected in 4Q19 (vs. GSe 4Q19 implied: 4.3%; 3Q19: 7.2%).
On LFL sales growth, SSP commented on resilient air traffic in the UK, whilst Rail remained softer albeit with a lower level of disruption. In Europe, LFL sales were held back by slower traffic in the Nordics and Spain. In North America, the grounding of Boeing Max 737 resulted in the transfer of passengers away from SSP terminals.
Strong net contract gains vs expectations were a result of new openings in North America, Europe but also the newly commenced operations in Brazil, which is a new territory for SSP.
In our view, given the current cyclical concerns, slowing LFL growth is likely to be taken cautiously by the market today. And whilst slower LFL growth is for now offset by stronger net additions, we add that this is likely to be margin dilutive over the near term, as it will be accompanied by pre-opening costs.

Blank canvas pancakes - you might just have a split personality - very handy in some circumstances
BE11:37am

And Canaccord.

BE11:38am

SSPG has reported that positive Q3 trends have continued into Q4 and FY19 guidance remains unchanged. A slightly less positive L4L sales performance has been offset by a slightly better level of new contract wins. Looking forward, lower L4L sales growth will not be fully offset by contract wins and we would expect consensus to edge down slightly for FY20. Growing international profits are attractive for investors seeking an element of 'Brexit hedge', we believe. We retain our HOLD recommendation and 710p share price target.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

SSPG had a good final quarter with group revenue +7.8% (constant currency +10%), comprising +1.8% L4L sales growth and +6.0% new contract wins. Full year net contract wins of +5.5% for the full year are just ahead of guidance but will come with higher associated pre-opening costs. As a consequence, margin progression will not be quite as good this year, but this is not a concern, in our view.
In the UK, the air sector has remained resilient but rail remains softer due to the disruption at several London terminals. In Continental Europe, performance has been held back by lower passenger growth and the impact of several airport redevelopments in the Nordic region and in Spain. In North America, L4L sales growth has been impacted by the grounding of the Boeing Max 737 aircraft and transfer for passengers away from terminals where SSPG is present. In RoW, it's been a mixed performance with Egypt and the Middle East performing strongly but India, China and now Hong Kong are trading less well. SSPG now says that group L4L sales for the group should be just below 2%. Looking forward to FY20E, we base our forecasts on 2% L4L sales growth, +2.9% new contract wins, 18bp margin expansion and a fractionally higher interest charge (+£1m).
We have left our currency assumption unchanged as we do not attempt to forecast exchange rates. We are most cautious of the RoW division as the region could be the most affected by an escalation in the US/China trade dispute which could affect travel as well as the ongoing disruption in India.
We forecast FY19E net debt of £484m (+£149m from FY18) and net debt/EBITDA of 1.5x driven by the £150m special dividend and a £15m increase in FY19E capex to £160m because of the higher contract wins. Nevertheless, SSP should delever quickly and we forecast net debt/EBITDA of just 1.0x for FY21E. This suggests another +£100m special dividend could be back on the menu in the next 18 months.

BE11:39am

Using today's opening price, SSPG is trading on a 22.3x P/E, an 10.3x EV/EBITDA and a FCF yield of 2.4% for 2019E, falling to 20.5x, 9.4x and 3.6% the following year. Our 710p target price remains based on 25x PE for FY19E. It is also equivalent to 11.3x EV/EBITDA and a 2.1% FCF yield. Quest® ascribes an adjusted value of 440p, 35% below the current price.

BE11:39am

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Anyway, today we get an exit from Thin Film activities and a £39m impairment

hornblower any comment on more write downs at WPCT
BE11:46am

Peel Hunt:

BE11:46am

H1 revenue was down 36% YoY at £22.5m, underlying pre-tax loss of £15.0m vs. £3.2m profit in prior year. Net cash £21.6m at 30th June. No dividend. Thin Film strategic review - The Board has concluded that without a strategic partner the Group is unable to fund the ongoing development and has decided to cease all Thin Film activities, resulting in a £39m impairment in H1 (£28.5m intangible assets, £5.4m PPE & £5.1m working capital balances). The remaining business will be right-sized, with annual cost savings of £8m implemented in H2, at a cash cost of £2.5m, to improve the profit performance in FY2020. Board Changes - CEO Doug Edwards will step down at the year end, replaced by the recently appointed head of the printhead business unit, John Mills. CFO Shomit Kenkare will also step down at the year end. Chairman Robin Williams will be replaced by current NED Andrew Herbert at the end of March and the SID Margaret Rice-Jones will not see re-election at the 2020 AGM. Outlook – expect sales in H2 to be similar to H1. Underlying trading in the Printhead business has stabilised and seeing good growth in Product Print Systems. Forecasts: We expect the FY pre-tax loss to be c£22m. For FY2020 the pre-tax loss is expected to reduce to £7m, albeit c.£5m of this will realte to Xaar 3D. We are reducing our target price to 85p, based on a crude sum-of-the-parts calculation. The year-end net cash is expected to be £25m (c.30p per share), net of the Stratasys 3D investment. We maintain our Hold recommendation.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

And Jefferies is no recommendation so just offers a summary.

BE11:47am

1H19 Interim Results: Xaar reported 1H19 sales of £22.5m (previously guided), some £12.8m lower YoY, although excluding the royalty payment non-repeat and the 1201 revenue reversal, there was 5% YoY growth. The 1H19 operating loss was £15.0m, (-£7.4m excluding the Xaar 1201 items) and the group has incurred £39m of impairment charges in the period. Net Cash at 30 Jun-19 was £21.6m (previously guided).

Segmental Performance: OCC Printhead sales were +1% (excluding the aforementioned revenue reversal); Product Printing sales were. +22% (OE sales +25%, consumables +15%) and this segment was break-even in the period; "significant progress" with Xaar 3D Printing has also been made in the period.

Strategic Review - Thin Film Activities Will Cease & Restructuring of Printhead Business: Mgmt has announced the decision to cease all Thin Film activities and restructure/reduce headcount, as without a strategic investment partner, it "becomes, by ourselves, unaffordable to continue". Ultimately, having engaged in a thorough process to identify a partner to provide scale and funding, there have been no viable proposals to recommend to shareholders. Mgmt recognise that on a stand-alone basis, the group is not generating sufficient cash to fund the development programme that is still not close to commercial levels of sales. Mgmt will continue to explore opportunities to licence the IP that has been built up. At the same time, mgmt will reduce costs (headcount/general costs) within its Bulk business, in an attempt to right-size it to "a level appropriate to the sales expected in the near-term". Restructuring of the Printhead business will result in £8m of benefits at a one-off cost of £2.5m.

Mgmt Succession: Having led the group's strategic review and next phase of the Stratsys 3D partnership to a conclusion, CEO Doug Edwards has informed the Board of his desire to leave to explore opportunities in the US, where his home/family are based. He will be replaced by John Mills, who joined the group as head of the Printhead BU in Aug-19, having previously worked for Domino Printing and most recently, he was the CEO of Inca Digitial ('an industry leader in the design, development and manufacture of inkjet printers for the print industry', based in Cambridge). John will replace Doug Edwards on 31 Dec-19, although Doug will remain available until 31 Mar-20 in order to ensure an orderly handover.

Additionally, Xaar today announces that Chairman, Robin Williams, having been a Board member for over 9 years, will step down from his position on 31 Mar-20 and will be replaced by Andrew Herbert (a NED of Xaar since Jun-16). Shomit Kenkare has resigned his role as CFO and will leave on 31 Dec-19 to pursue opportunities back in the US. The group's SID will also leave the group post the FY20F AGM.

BE11:59am

While the impact of the pilot strike was expected, the continued weakness in intra-europe highlights the challenges to the industry. Against this difficult background, we continue to see IAG as offering the best risk-reward. IAG reduced expectations for 2019: This came broadly in line with our expectations and consensus due to the pilot strikes in London during September, which explain c60% of the profit warning.

BE12:00pm

Further weakness in Hong Kong and strikes at Heathrow explain another €33mn shortfall. The incremental negative, albeit small to the size of IAG, is the weakness in the yields of its low cost carriers Level and Vueling (see here for details) for flights in October and November. We fine tune our estimates to incorporate weaker growth in 2019 and 2020.Latam and Intra-Europe continue to show signs of weakness - we would expect more warnings to follow. During the management conference call today, IAG said the main points of weakness in its low cost operators came from Italy, France and UK passengers into Spain (for Vueling), which the Spanish domestic market remains strong. And at Level, Latam (Argentina, and also Chile) are the key weak points. Even though we could attribute part of the Vueling weakness to company specific issues (strikes in Barcelona may have caused the need for lower yields), as AF-KLM has also warned on weak late bookings we suspect this is a broader issue. As shown below, Ryanair, easyJet and AF-KLM have the largest overlap with Vueling routes and Lufthansa group, AF-KLM and easyJet have the largest overlap with Level, therefore these airlines could also been impacted by weakness in yields. Management see capacity growth slowing into 2020. The slower growth has been a common theme for airlines, and while this could be a sign of more discipline, and therefore, positive for the sector, due to continued weaking yields, we do not think this is yet a reason for optimism. The weakness in yields in one of the reasons we are cautious on EU airlines (Airlines: Time to buy? Not yet (18 Sep 2019). We remain Overweight, as we think IAG offers the best risk-reward in the sector. We do not anticipate a sharp negative earnings revision from consensus on the back of this news. Year to date, IAG PE had a multiple contraction of 1.6x, 0.25x more than peers. Despite having above average FCF generation, returns and cost execution, IAG is trading at trough multiples both in absolute (4.2x 2-year forward PE) and relative terms (0.6x sector PE, vs historical trading at 0.8x). Moreover, IAG EV/IC relative to premium over cost of capital is amongst the most attractive in the sector. This signals to us that the negatives have been priced in more so than at peers. And, if the outlook improves and IAG delivers on its medium-term targets (our bull case), the upside to shares would be ~100%. Next catalysts for the stock are results on 31 October and Capital markets day on 5 November.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

IAG has adjusted its guidance for an operating profit before exceptional
items to be EUR215m below 2018 pro forma level of EUR3,485m (vs. flat
before). The guidance adjustment is driven by an estimated net financial
impact from BALPA’s (BA’s main pilots’ union) industrial action EUR137m
and from threatened strikes by Heathrow employees of EUR33m. In
addition, the company expects the latest booking trends in its low cost
segment (Vueling and LEVEL) to have an adverse financial impact of
EUR45m. Overall, IAG expects passenger unit revenues to be slightly down at constant currency in 2019E (vs. flat before) and as previously guided, non-fuel unit cost is expected to improve at constant currency. The company is expecting to increase capacities by only 2% in Q4 (vs. +3.2%
before). Our 2019E operating result for IAG of EUR3,220m has been
below the company’s previous guidance and is largely in line with the
company’s new guidance of EUR3,270m. Reuters consensus of
EUR3,309m is only marginally above guidance. We apply a 10% discount
on the EV/EBITDAR 2019E multiple of 4x that we apply to value Lufthansa, to account for Brexit-related uncertainties.

BE12:02pm

Beyond the knee-jerk sell-off in IAG LN shares, we think the
6% EBIT cut is better than the over 30% cut the shares price-in to €2.4bn
EBIT for FY19E and FY20E at 4.5x EV/EBITDA multiple. (After its profit
warnings, LHA GY shares have seen their multiple return to ~4.5x EV/
EBITDA RBCe). To reach this in FY20E, IAG needs to see an ~5% fall
in unit revenues/RASK. While the economic outlook is soft (European
composite PMI just more than 50, and UK politics continues to be shambolic) we think: (1) Economic signals are weak, not full blown recessionary at present (needed for this type of RASK drop); and, (2) There is a helpful capacity outlook emerging for this winter, especially intra-Europe and Irish Trans Atlantic sees no growth to seats supply shrinkage - which will be average fare price and thus profit supportive we think.
